Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Enabling Risk-Aware Decision Making in Human-Guided Unmanned Surface Vehicle Teams

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the last ten years, substantial progress has been made in the development of small low-cost unmanned surface vehicles (USVs). There are a number of civilian applications where deploying a human-robot team consisting of several small USVs and one or more human supervisors can significantly reduce costs, improve safety, and increase operational efficiencies. Representative applications include remote/persistent ocean sensing, marine search and rescue, maritime operations in congested port environments, and industrial offshore supply and support. USVs face unique challenges that are not experienced by robots operating indoors, such as: the need to adhere to marine navigation rules (COLREGs); local current, wave and wind conditions that can severely reduce the dynamic range of sensors and actuators; frequent communication interruptions; and risk and urgency due to rapidly changing situations during outdoor on-water operations. This research aims to develop decision making foundations for enabling teams of humans and USVs to perform complex collaborative tasks. Advances in this area could be extremely important from both a regulatory and practical standpoint for the future deployment of USV systems. Results from this research will enable leveraging the tremendous potential of USVs by reducing the cost of deployment and operational risks in civilian applications. The integration of the research with graduate and undergraduate courses will enhance the robotics and ocean engineering curricula and enrich learning experiences of the participating students. Outreach activities will educate and inform K-12 students about career opportunities in marine robotics.

The overall goal of the proposed effort is to make advances in risk-informed decision making so that teams of USVs and human supervisors can work cooperatively on a wide variety of missions. The proposed work will develop a comprehensive distributed decision making approach by leveraging the latest advances in task coordination and assignment, planning, reactive behaviors, and control to enable the deployment of human-guided USV teams in civilian applications. Progress in these constituent components will be pursued to ensure that they are consistent with each other and to explicitly account for risk during decision making. This research will develop methodologies to model team missions to ensure that all phases of decision making will have the required information for making informed decisions. Decision making methodologies will be developed for sparse advisory control of USV teams to mitigate risks and for coordinating and assigning tasks to different USVs in the team. Algorithms will also be developed for risk-aware deliberative trajectory planning and generating and executing reactive behaviors for mitigating risks. The methods developed will be validated through on-water field experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

There are a number of civilian applications where deploying a human-robot team consisting of several small unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) and one or more human supervisors can significantly reduce costs, improve safety, and increase operational efficiencies. Representative applications include remote/persistent ocean sensing, marine search and rescue, maritime operations incongested port environments, and industrial offshore supply and support.

USVs face unique challenges that are not experienced by robots operating indoors, such as: the need to adhere to marine navigation rules (COLREGs); local current, wave and wind conditions that can severely reduce the dynamic range of sensors and actuators; frequent communication interruptions; and risk and urgency due to rapidly changing situationsduring outdoor on-water operations.

The overall goal of the effort is to make advances in risk-informed decision making so that teams of USVs and human supervisors can work cooperatively on a wide variety of missions.

Intellectual Merit:

The research has made the following intellectual contributions:

1) Methodologies to model team missions to ensure that all phases of decision making will have the required information for making informed decisions,

2) Risk-aware methods for coordinating and assigning tasks to different USVs in the team,

These first two contributions are encapsulated in a Robot Operating System based mission interface and simulation, which was developed to permit a "ship pilot", ground crew and teams of USVs to communicate, monitor the progress of a docking operation, and share task execution and assignment.

3) Decision making methodologies for sparse advisory control of USV teams to mitigate risks,

We extensively explored the use of shared control, in which the control signals from both a human and automatic control system are mixed so that the instantaneous behavior of the robot represents a the combined inputs, the so-called "Mixed Initiative" Approach. The approach we developed is centered on a) measuring a human's intent to control the robot via a novel way of isolating the human's input from external disturbances during the computation of a parameter known as the "pseudo power"; b) using the measured pseudo power as a means to continuously switch between the human input and the input from the automatic controller; and c) a means of rescaling the combined control input to ensure the stability of the shared human-robot system. As the stability of shared human-robot control is relatively unexplored, we feel that this last contribution is very promising for enabling more widespread implementation of shared control.

4) Algorithms for risk-aware deliberative trajectory planning,

Our partner, USC, led the development of a wave-aware trajectory planner for USVs operating in congested port environments. We contributed to the development of this planner by providing a means to numerically simulate the wave fields behind moving vessels. The PIs and Students from FAU and USC met in Florida to jointly perform a series of field experiments to test the planner using the facilities and instrumentation at FAU.

We also developed a computationally efficient trajectory planner for marine vehicles, which minimizes the energy usage of the vehicle over the course of the trajectory. The novelty of our approach is that it uses advanced techniques from geometric control theory to provide a means of rapidly computing an efficient trajectory. The technique avoids a mathematical singularity problem often encountered when using other methods, so that it can be used to solve a larger range of trajectory planning problems. 

5) Algorithms for generating and executing reactive behaviors for mitigating risks.

We developed several new algorithms for the reactive control of unmanned marine vehicles, which makes them more robust to disturbances (e.g. currents, wind, waves) than other approaches. These algorithms implement several recently developed techniques in nonlinear control theory, including nonlinear backstepping, higher order sliding mode control, and dynamic surface control. Our algorithms take risk into account by incorporating the limitations of actuators, such the maximum thrust available from propellers, while ensuring that the controlled systems can stably operate in environments with uncertain and sometimes large disturbances.

Broader Impacts:

The challenges of creating fully autonomous USVs capable of human-like decision making in a constantly changing environment are immense. An approach that teams up humans and robots in the decision making process can be more cost and time-effective in leveraging the tremendous potential of USVs. Advances in this area could be an extremely important from both a regulatory and practical standpoint for the future deployment of USV systems.

The research conducted under this work has been included in robotics and ocean engineering curricula, at both the graduate and undergraduate levels: (1) a textbook on the control of marine vehicles has been submitted for publication - much of the work on the low, level reactive control of unmanned marine vehicles develope for this project has been included;

(2) the PI has presented some of the results of this work at a special workshop on robotics aimed at PhD-level students.
